entry.title: Touring UTIG's Airplane
entry.summary:
Don Blankenship's research group at UTIG has been collecting geophysical data in Antarctica for decades. Each season, we hire Kenn Borek Air1 to operate one of their modified airplanes, stuff it full of sensors, and fly around Antarctica. This post attempts to give a tour of the hardware involved, with an emphasis on its scientific purpose and a detour through Antarctic logistics.

Why aerogeophysics?

Antarctica is huge and hard to access. While some types of data require in situ measurements (and are collected by overland traverses or teams dropped off by helicopter), the most efficient way to obtain basic information about the thickness of the ice and properties of the rock underneath it is to mount sensors in an airplane and start flying. This type of mapping is inherently 1D in nature - we obtain very dense observations along a flight line, then interpolate tens of kilometers between the lines to create a map.

The left plot above shows everwhere that BEDMAP22 has data. Almost all of the black lines represent a single flight line. The densest (apparently solid) regions of black lines correspond to grids with 5km line spacing. The right plot shows where my research group has flown over the past few decades. Until this season, there were places where the closest measurement was hundreds of kilometers away.3

The airplane (and logistics)

My research group currently uses WWII-era DC-3s,4 like the one in the picture at the start of this post.5 We've used these since 2007. All through the 1990's and early 2000's, they used a Twin Otter (below). Conceptually, not much has changed - while we're continually upgrading the instruments, the same types of data have been being collected for over 20 years.

Each season is slightly different, but a common pattern is to ship everything to a larger coastal station (McMurdo or Casey), do our setup and test flights from there, then fly to another base or field camp or series of bases closer to where we want to collect data, spend anywhere from a few days to a month at each spot, then head back to the bigger station for deconfiguration and getting home. Cargo usually travels to Antarctica on an airplane and returns on an icebreaker,6 while humans usually travel both ways in a C-17 or LC-1307 operated by the Air National Guard flying to and from Christchurch, New Zealand.

I may have mentioned stuffing the airplane full:

The above images are from transit flights, when we had way more people and baggage than for normal survey operations. The right photo was taken looking from the center of the plane towards the back. In it, we can see part of rack 4 (used for HF radar electronics), the photon counting lidar with its control laptop8 on top, and the curtain that separates the heated part of the plane from the cargo doors.

From a similar location but looking forward (and taken on a non-transit flight!) we get a nice look at the racks in the front half of the airplane:

Starting at the cockpit, we have:

  • rack 1 - operator interface, VHF amplifier
  • rack 2 - VHF radar electronics
  • black box - gravimeter
  • rack 3 - gravimeter electronics

It takes an absolute minimum of 2 days to install all of this, several more for test flights to make sure everything works, and a very full day at the end of the season to strip it all out and start packing to go home.

Any Kenn Borek airplane comes with 3 people dedicated to its operation: a mechanic (who is usually waiting back at the station), a pilot, and a copilot. Here are Kevin (left) and John (right), our pilots last season.

We find that the DC-3 has the best tradeoff for fuel burned per line-km of data collected.9 This airplane burns ~100010 pounds per hour,11 travels at a nominal cruising speed of 160 knots, and has an endurance of ~6.5 hours in survey configuration.12 So, for every day of good weather, we can get up to 2000 line-km of data. If the weather has been bad and the pilots have extra hours available, we might do two 5-hour flights rather than a single 6.5 hour one, but that's the maximum for a single flight crew.13

Antarctic weather is usually the biggest challenge to successfully flying all of the survey lines that we've planned. At a rough estimate, we're only able to fly 1/2 of the days when the airplane is available. The biggest worry here is the ability to land. When you're using snow for a runway, it doesn't take much in the way of clouds or fog to ruin all contrast. Add a few more clouds or some snow falling from the sky as in the picture above, and it can be hard to find the horizon when you're just walking around. Clouds are also a problem because of the potential for the wings - or worse, the radar antennas - to ice up. Where we were operating last season, there were no good alternative runways, which meant that we were only able to fly when the weather was forecast to be pristine for the next ~8 hours.14

Once we have everything installed and are airborne, what data are we collecting?

VHF Radar

The most visible external modifications that we make to the airplane are the antennas installed under each wing for the VHF radar. While the receiver electronics have changed multiple times since then, these antennas are the same ones that were used back in the 1970's for some of the first ice-penetrating radar surveys of Antarctica.15 Both antennas are used for transmitting the 8kW signal and for receiving the much weaker echoes.

We use this 60MHz radar to get a 2D cross-section of the ice. An example of the data is shown above - you can clearly see the ice surface, layers within the ice, and mountains underneath. I've previously talked about interpreting the radargrams, so I won't go further into it here.

The most basic science done with data from this sensor is determining the topography underneath kilometers of ice. Among other things, this is important for calculating how much potential sea level change is locked up in Antarctica, and how stable the ice sheet is likely to be.

We are proud of having collected a significant portion of the line-km that were used to create Bedmap2.16 Bedmap217 is the most recent compilation of Antarctic ice-depth and sub-ice topography data.18 The image above shows the bed elevation - note how much of the continent is actually lower than sea level!

HF radar

In addition to the 60MHz VHF radar, we also field a 2MHz HF radar. Rather than antennas under the wings, we unspool a \(\sim\)60m long wire antenna through a port in the floor. My attempts to get a clear picture of this antenna deployed while in flight have failed, so the best I have is one of Jamin preparing to reel the antenna back in.

The main factors determining how deep of a bed we can detect is the radar signal's attenuation as it passes through the ice. Both warmer ice and saltier ice lead to higher losses, as does a rough surface that causes scattering. In some conditions, energy at 2MHz penetrates better than energy at 60MHz, at the cost of poorer vertical resultion due to the much longer wavelength.

We primarily fly this dual-frequency setup as a testbed for the REASON instrument that will be on the next mission to Europa.

Gravity

I'm continually amazed that we're able to measure accelarations accurately enough to infer underwater topography based on local changes in gravitational acceleration. Stationary instruments on the ground can measure to a precision of ~5uGal. For context, the gravity field changes by ~300uGal/m as you get farther from the center of the earth, and 1G = 9.8m/s2 = 980Gal. From a moving platform with turbulance, we'll get precision on the order of a few mGal. This requires integrating many measurements in order to get a usable signal to noise ratio, which means that we're only able to detect features on the scale of ~5km.19 The main complication when interpreting gravity data is that you're actually measuring differences in density. If you assume less-dense sedimentary rocks underneath the water, you're going to wind up balancing them out with a shallower water column, while if you assume denser rocks, you'll infer deeper water.

Jamin Greenbaum recently published a paper20 improving the estimates of the cavity shape underneath the Totten Ice Shelf. His inferred geometry is shown below on the left.

This was an important result because he showed that the ocean is deep enough that warm deep water is able to enter the cavity, which could explain why the glacier's surface is lowering so quickly. It was also a significant improvement over the previous bathymetry - in the figure above right, you can see the old best-guess bathymetry as a dashed line.

Magnetics

We have two magnetometers on the plane. One is mounted inside near the cameras and and measures the 3 dimensional magnetic field vector. A much more precise one measuring only the magnitude is stuck way at the end of the tail boom, shown above. The idea behind this arrangement is that we want to understand how the airplane's orientation and interaction with the earth's magnetic field affects the measured field (you can see turns very clearly in the interior data), but we want the most accurate reading possible, taken as far away as possible from all the metal in the plane.

We also record the magnetic field at a base station. The above image shows the magnetometer housing and its solar charger. Data from this is used to determine when to fly (it gets noisier at certain times of day) and then compared with the in-flight data to determine an anomaly. Any signal that's different between the base and the airplane can be assumed to be from local topography, not the earth's temporally varying magnetic field.

Igneous rocks tend to be magnetic, with their internal field aligned with what the earth's field was when the rock formed, while ice and sedimentary rocks are not magnetic. This means that we can figure out what type of rocks are underneath the ice based on the magnetic signal that we observe! This process has been used to infer the presence of shallow volcanoes underneath the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. This matches very well with other observations indicating that the ice sheet is warmer and melting more than you'd expect for somewhere with globally average geothermal flux.

Determining the depth of the magnetic rocks can also be useful for interpreting gravity data. If something's magnetic, you know that it's denser than sediments would be, and anything that helps you constrain the density model will improve the gravity inversion. Depth can be inferred from the signal's gradient - the deeper a feature is, the smoother the resulting signal will be.

Cameras

We don't use camera data directly to answer any science questions,21 but the pictures are useful for providing context for other data. This has included trying to figure out why we were missing laser data: Was it cloudy out? Were we in a heavily crevassed region? Were we over water? It has also been used to validate radar-derived surface roughness estimates. The below figure is from a paper by Cyril Grima22 and shows roughness parameters derived from a statistical examination of the returned radar pulse shape. The extracted parameters show an excellent qualitative agreement with the imagery.

Laser altimetry

We use lasers to very accurately measure the surface elevation of the ice sheet. Even where it is changing most rapidly, these changes are measured in meters per year, and our goal is to be able to detect changes of 5cm per year. From 2003-2009, ICESat collected laser altimetry from space, leading to a detailed map of where elevations are changing across Antarctica and Greenland.23

However, ICESat failed in 2009, and its replacement has not yet been launched. So, a number of groups (including ours) have been reflying ICESat tracks in an effort to extend the temporal record and hopefully connect it to ICESat II. Our system, ALAMO24, includes an off-the-shelf single-beam Riegl altimeter, which is well characterized and used to determine the range to the surface. We also have a more temperamental scanning photon counting lidar that is a protopype of what will be on ICESat II. Its data points are dense enough to map individual buildings in McMurdo (below), but we mostly use its data to determine the ice's surface slope, which is important when trying to compare two slightly offset repeat flights of the same line.

GPS, IMU

We have 4 GPS antennas mounted outside the plane: at the center, the tail, and on each wing. These are used to get absolute position in space. The IMUs measure accelations, and give us a very accurate orientation estimate - we have a little MEMs one mounted on rack 2, and a more precise one mounted directly to the PCL. After post-processing, we typically know our position to \(\sim\)2cm and our orientation to milli-radian accuracy.

While we don't use this as science data in and of itself, knowing the airplane's exact position is absolutely crucial for processing the other data. For example, the laser altimetry measurements are basically a 600m lever arm, and if we want to know the position of the end of that arm to centimeter accuracy, orientation matters.

Outside Air Temperature, Pressure

This is more metadata for our operation than science data. No major publications result from this, but I did use them to validate a correction for the speed of light in air, which primarily depends on pressure and temperature. I was utterly dumbfounded when I realized that the difference in conditions between the coast and inland domes could result in a 10cm bias in the altimetry data! We don't consistently collect temperature and pressure data, but we always know our altitude. So, I needed to check that an altitude-based approximation to the speed of light would remove any geographical bias in our data.25

entry.title: Working at Progress Airfield
entry.summary:
I spent this field season as a member of CHINARE 32, supporting the operation of their brand-new airplane that is being used to collect geophysical data about Antarctica. This airplane operated out of the Progress runway, which is a rugged 30-60 minute drive from the main station. In order to make the logistics simpler, Chinare set up a camp for the fixed-wing team right next to the runway. This was fantastically convenient - whenever the airplane was flying, the whole science team was able to live up there.

We weren't the only ones using the runway - (ALCI)[http://???] operates logistics flights. When I'm in the field, my job is to process all of the data that is being collected. We try to have all of this processing done before the next flight takes off - one of the most important parts of my job is providing this feedback to the flight operations team. entry.title: Russian Tanks of the Antarctic
Xuelong: 2.5 Weeks on an Icebreaker
entry.summary:
We left the Xuelong for Zhongshan station a month ago, but we've been so busy since then it feels like much longer. I've finally gotten enough time to put together some pictures from our remarkably enjoyable and relaxing time on the boat.

We departed from Fremantle, Australia on November 22, a few days ahead of schedule. Most of the people on the Xuelong had boarded in Shanghai a few weeks earlier.

The ping pong table was centrally located just outside the first floor dining room. This was the leisure activity of choice on board the Xuelong, and we had the treat of watching Dr. Sun win the ship-wide tournament. Dr. Guo was kind enough to play against Jamin and I and give us pointers, and we quickly got into the habit of staying up late so we could play when everybody else was asleep. (It helped that they always served noodles or dumplings at 11pm.) The door in the background leads down to this passage

which makes it possible to get from the front (where all the bedrooms and common areas are) to the back (where the engine and helicopters are) without having to go outside into bad weather.

Both Dr. Sun and Dr. Guo gave me a tour of the engine room (I forgot my camera the first time!)

I was surprised by how comfortable the ship was - three of us shared this room (I had the top left bunk), and we even had our own private bathroom, complete with shower.

I consistently felt welcome and accepted on the Xuelong. I really like being in a place where everybody says "hello" or "ni hao" with a smile when passing in the hallways.

We spent a lot of time hanging out in the second floor dining room. It was the main social gathering spot - I learned to play a popular card game (5-10-King) and Chinese Chess. At night, it was peaceful, and I really enjoyed working in a spot with natural light and views.

In general the food was good - our colleagues were endearingly but needlessly worried about this. I got to try some things I'd never had before, including eel and bullfrog. One of the big social events of the trip was the dumpling making party pictured above. We were eating them for days afterwards.

I also spent a fair bit of time outside on the various decks, just enjoying watching the ice pass by. We were allowed to wander pretty much anywhere, and the Xuelong is big enough I never felt cabin fever. This view was nice because it was usually out of the wind, and it gave me a good look at the Xuelong. It never stopped being surreal that I was in the middle of the ocean on a Chinese icebreaker. All of the drums of fuel on the deck are meant for the airplane that we'll be using for our data collection. Our instruments are in the hold - once the fuel was removed, massive doors swung up and the cranes lifted out the shipping containers.

Of course, the best views on the ship were from the bridge. One floor down, in the weather office, there were also great views and an open invitation to stop by for tea and snacks.

The only place the satellite phone reliably worked was on the very top deck, amidst the antennas and various science equipment, exposed to the wind.

Once we broke through hundreds of meters of ice and parked, this was my favorite view on the ship. The penguins loved this bit of open water, and we could almost always see a few somewhere nearby.

After we were parked, we were allowed off the boat. Here I'm posing with my roommates. You can see our window - we were on the 5th floor (2 below the bridge), second from right in this view. One morning I was baffled by an almost-dead cellphone, until I discovered a text message "Welcome to China! Your roaming rates are ...". Surprise! Not only does Zhongshan station have 3G coverage, but it occasionally reached us on the Xuelong.

The penguins were entirely unfazed by the humans.

However, they skedaddled in an adorable panic when the helicopter appeared. There was a large crack in the sea ice near the station, so the entire resupply was done by helicopter, rather than driving the ~20km over the ice.

And, we're leaving! This was my first helicopter ride, and I was lucky enough to have a window view. Given that we were in the hold of a cargo helicopter, most people didn't.

entry.title: Apostasy, Step 1: Surviving Vim
entry.summary:
My colleagues objected to installing emacs on our robot and I find nano woefully insufficient, so I finally admitted that I have to learn vim. Until recently, all I knew was :q!, and I used it with extreme prejudice.

It took me a while to not hate vim, and I still prefer emacs despite not being a power-user in the least. My problem with vim is that I really struggle with remembering which mode I am in. I think the key here is to always leave it in command mode unless you're actively inserting text. I should have taken the hint from how command mode is also called normal mode, but it took a while for this to click.

The other main thing to realize is that compands are composable, such that :w is save and :q is quit, so :wq is save and quit. I suspect that this becomes even more powerful once you're more fluent.

There have been silver linings for me:

  • I can use the default GNU screen configuration on the robot without the usual Ctrl-a headache in emacs.
  • I've fallen in love with the "delete to" command. It is exactly how I frame the operation in my head, and I've yet to find an emacs alternative that doesn't require lots of repetitive keystrokes.

Links/References/Configuration

  • Why the heck would you use the least-accessible key on the keyboard for the most-critical key in vim? I assume that everybody remaps it: I chose CapsLock, which was a win all around.

  • This post about how vim's big idea is composability did a great job putting editor history into perspective for me.

entry.title: Touring UTIG's Airplane
entry.summary:
Don Blankenship's research group at UTIG has been collecting geophysical data in Antarctica for decades. Each season, we hire Kenn Borek Air1 to operate one of their modified airplanes, stuff it full of sensors, and fly around Antarctica. This post attempts to give a tour of the hardware involved, with an emphasis on its scientific purpose and a detour through Antarctic logistics.

Why aerogeophysics?

Antarctica is huge and hard to access. While some types of data require in situ measurements (and are collected by overland traverses or teams dropped off by helicopter), the most efficient way to obtain basic information about the thickness of the ice and properties of the rock underneath it is to mount sensors in an airplane and start flying. This type of mapping is inherently 1D in nature - we obtain very dense observations along a flight line, then interpolate tens of kilometers between the lines to create a map.

The left plot above shows everwhere that BEDMAP22 has data. Almost all of the black lines represent a single flight line. The densest (apparently solid) regions of black lines correspond to grids with 5km line spacing. The right plot shows where my research group has flown over the past few decades. Until this season, there were places where the closest measurement was hundreds of kilometers away.3

The airplane (and logistics)

My research group currently uses WWII-era DC-3s,4 like the one in the picture at the start of this post.5 We've used these since 2007. All through the 1990's and early 2000's, they used a Twin Otter (below). Conceptually, not much has changed - while we're continually upgrading the instruments, the same types of data have been being collected for over 20 years.

Each season is slightly different, but a common pattern is to ship everything to a larger coastal station (McMurdo or Casey), do our setup and test flights from there, then fly to another base or field camp or series of bases closer to where we want to collect data, spend anywhere from a few days to a month at each spot, then head back to the bigger station for deconfiguration and getting home. Cargo usually travels to Antarctica on an airplane and returns on an icebreaker,6 while humans usually travel both ways in a C-17 or LC-1307 operated by the Air National Guard flying to and from Christchurch, New Zealand.

I may have mentioned stuffing the airplane full:

The above images are from transit flights, when we had way more people and baggage than for normal survey operations. The right photo was taken looking from the center of the plane towards the back. In it, we can see part of rack 4 (used for HF radar electronics), the photon counting lidar with its control laptop8 on top, and the curtain that separates the heated part of the plane from the cargo doors.

From a similar location but looking forward (and taken on a non-transit flight!) we get a nice look at the racks in the front half of the airplane:

Starting at the cockpit, we have:

  • rack 1 - operator interface, VHF amplifier
  • rack 2 - VHF radar electronics
  • black box - gravimeter
  • rack 3 - gravimeter electronics

It takes an absolute minimum of 2 days to install all of this, several more for test flights to make sure everything works, and a very full day at the end of the season to strip it all out and start packing to go home.

Any Kenn Borek airplane comes with 3 people dedicated to its operation: a mechanic (who is usually waiting back at the station), a pilot, and a copilot. Here are Kevin (left) and John (right), our pilots last season.

We find that the DC-3 has the best tradeoff for fuel burned per line-km of data collected.9 This airplane burns ~100010 pounds per hour,11 travels at a nominal cruising speed of 160 knots, and has an endurance of ~6.5 hours in survey configuration.12 So, for every day of good weather, we can get up to 2000 line-km of data. entry.title: Your next robotics project should use ROS
entry.summary:
After predominantly using ROS for a few years, I'm working on a project where the team has cobbled together their own middleware.

I miss ROS. I think that it should be the default choice for a new robotics project: rather than the discussion being framed as "Why ROS?", I want it to be "Why not ROS?"

Reasons I've heard as to why people chose not to use ROS:

  1. None of the drivers/higher-level packages apply to my project, so why bother?
  2. Hella-steep learning curve / I started the tutorials but couldn't see what was in it for my project.
  3. If I use ROS, I'm committing wholesale to ROS and are stuck using their paradigm. You can't really grab the just bits of it that you want.
  4. My project is too simple to need it.

My goal is to:

  • Show that #1 is irrelevant.
  • I'm not going to argue with #2. However, I'll try to convince you that the stuff you get by using ROS offers good enough default tools to give it a try despite #2.
  • Of course, if #3 is truly a problem for you (other than at a philosophical level), you'll either know ROS's limitations better than I do, and have an exact reason that it's unsatisfactory for your application, OR be part of an existing team with the resources to have already developed mature middleware suitable for your project.
  • Quantify when #4 is true.

So, what do I miss? (aka stuff I'd taken for granted until having to cobble together a non-ROS solution)

  • The messaging system. After having struggled with LCM for a while now, I highly prefer ROS's functionality. (I've only briefly played with protobufs, and am not familiar with any other systems. I'd love to learn about other competitors!) I'll get to the tools for examining messages later; what I'm referring to here is how the message handling actually happens. I find ROS's spinOnce() idea to be exactly what I want in a not-fully-callback-driven main loop. It calls all callbacks for messages already in the queue, and then returns control. (If it were to call callbacks until the queue is empty, it'll never return if messages come in faster than they can be processed.) LCM, in contrast, exposes a blocking handle() call, that calls a single callback. I also like having the ActionServer built in. When designing more complicated behaviors, I often want a supervisory program to pass off control to another module, but with the option to monitor progress and cancel the goal. This is another thing that I expect to find myself re-creating.

  • tf The brilliant and simple idea behind tf is that all measurements should be tagged with the frame of reference that they were taken in relation to. Combine this with the idea that transformations between frames should also be published separately, and you get a utility that will let you translate data between any connected set of frames, as they were at any given point in time. I'm working on my own poor replacement, because I hate having to think about quaternions while working on what should be higher-level algorithms. There are also some nifty tools for debugging how you've set up the transform tree for your robot: visualize them in rviz, run tf_viewer, look at tf_echo.

  • rviz (so valuable to be able to plot arbitrary messages in 3d)
  • time - If you use system time in your programs to determine timeouts, then as soon as you try to run them faster in simulation, you're in trouble. ROS handles this by ....
  • rostopic. I'm using LCM right now (which could be a comparison post in its own right), and by its very nature it doesn't
  • config system (I'm meh about how they do it - I often find myself digging through tons of files to figure out where some parameter gets set and where all it could be overwritten. Still, writing your own distributed config system sucks; though a small enough project could probably use a simple yaml file)
  • roslaunch - another one that I'm meh on. If you're running nodes on multiple machines, you want a single point at which to start them all. I'm not in love with roslaunch; I'd love a way to interactively start/stop processes, and to open up an xterm (without having to have set that.
  • smach - It provides a state machine framework that is very well matched to the needs of a roboticist who is trying to design behaviors and contingency plans. Huge props to jbohren for architecting it in such a way that I can use the core functionality on even non-ROS projects!

Note that these are features of the core system; even if I was working on a robot for which there were no drivers or path planning packages available, I'd still benefit from ROS. Yes, I love that I can borrow a SICK laser scanner from another lab and have integration be trivial with my robot since good drivers exist within ROS, but that's just a bonus compared to how much work good-enough middleware saves you.

And, a bit about the bad stuff:

I find answers.ros.org to be enormously frustrating. Answering questions requires wading through large numbers of poorly-written and duplicate queries where the author hasn't put in the effort to ask a good question, and finding relevant questions is . There are plenty of resources to help write good questions; I wish that the admins would be more aggressive about encouraging people to improve their questions or have them removed. (I suspect that they've made a conscious decision to attempt to be more welcoming, at the expense of a less-useful Q-and-A site.) (TODO: link to lots of different sites discussing that.). The search has historically been broken - use google with site:answers.ros.org instead. However, the developers at OSRF do monitor it, and most answerable questions wind up with some attempt at an answer.

It's monolithic. If you want to use ROS, you can't really go halfway. AFAIK, all of the tools are intimately tied to the messaging system, and you'll have to have a single machine running the master node. I briefly looked at trying to peel TF off, but settled for writing a poor clone of it.

Finally, catkin. I've found the documentation to be confusing, and the errors cryptic. jbohren's tutorial really helps, but even in a team where everybody had been using ROS for years, it was common to lose hours to catkin. Catkin is the main reason that I didn't push hard for my current project to adopt ROS.

The learning curve is a pain. I was lucky enough to get started with ROS by joining an established team already using it; this is definitely the easiest way =) Tutorials are an awful place to throw a first-timer. I learned this the hard way, when trying to entice people to play with my robots at Hacker School. Even the motivated ones were turned off by the tutorials. I wish I had a better suggestion; the learning curve is steep, because it's a complicated system, but I wish there were a better place to point people for guidance in starting their own project.

So, why shouldn't you use ROS?

  • If your system is simple enough that the added complexity isn't worth it. ROS isn't meant for the simplest hobbyist-type robots: If the sense-think-act loop can literally run in one process, ROS is utterly unnecessary. If you have only a few processes, it might make sense to just use LCM or protobufs for message handling. However, even in that case, ROS's better infrastructure for monitoring communications can speed up debugging, and the various plotting tools are still fantastic.
  • You already know exactly why ROS won't work for you, and you have the resources to devote to developing all of your own middleware and tools.
  • If you're developing the next generation of robotics middleware - I'd love to see some competition!

Finally, why haven't I pushed for my current project to use ROS? In order of importance:

I'm the junior developer joining an existing team of 5, some of whom had been working on the code base for years. I didn't have a deep enough understanding of the system to confidently say that ROS would be good for this project, given our ambitious deadline and the inevitable ramp-up time.

Catkin. I don't want to try to get 5 other developers up-to-speed on it, when I don't understand it well myself.

I've realized that I default to assuming a ROS-like system when developing a robot - I thought I'd learn a lot by working on another project without it.

However, if the existing team starts a new project, I am optimistic that they will give ROS a much more serious look.

entry.summary:
Required Images / things to follow up on: (If I could flip back and forth between images, rather than putting them side-by-side, it'd look great)

  1. Pik1 for TOT/JKB2d/X16a (watermarked with UTIG, not full transect in order to fit side-by-side)
  2. raw data for same segment as (1). Try taking the log before plotting? Maybe plot magnitude instead?
  3. How fast does HiCARS2/MARFA actually sample? I've seen 6250 - 6408.
  4. Check up on my description of instrument coherence.
  5. Check up on and include details about what changed between our incoherent and coherent systems.
  6. Double-check the HiCARS2 pre-recording stacking depth
  7. Image showing no stacking, good stacking, and too much stacking (will require a sloped suface? I'll bet that DVD01a is a great test for this.)
  8. Better explanation of SAR.
  9. Cartoons showing the geometry for surface slope and pulse-limited footprint. I'm thinking something like I did for hyperbolae?

I'm used to looking at radargrams like the one above and left. That's the format we use for field quality control and preliminary science (we call that data product ``pik1''), so I tend to think of it as the most primitive form of the data. Significantly more complicated processing occurs once we get the data back to our server. However, as shown to the right, the raw data coming off the airplane is much uglier. Incomprehensible, even. In this post I'm going to explore the (very basic, but still magical) signal processing involved in this transformation.1

Recall that the radar sends out pulses of energy at 6400Hz.2 The sequential pulse numbers are the radargram's x-axis units, called traces, sweeps, or slow-time, and they roughly correspond to distance along the flight line.3 Each pulse is sampled at a frequency of 50MHz a total of 3437 times. We call these samples or fast-time. They're plotted on the y-axis of radargrams, and correspond to distance below the plane. This previous post goes into what is actually involved in collecting this data.

The radargram is simply an image showing how much energy was received at each sample of each trace, which images a virtual cross-section of the ice sheet. One thing to keep in mind when interpreting these images is that light travels faster through air than ice, so by comparison, the ice will look thicker. I've previously described a little bit of what goes into interpreting this data.

The actual field processing is pretty simple in concept:

  • Coherently stack 10 traces: boosts the signal to noise ratio
  • Dechirp (and denoise): improves vertical resolution, sharpens interfaces, removes noise due to the local oscillator
  • Incoherently stack 5 traces: removes speckle, further boosts SNR

The rest of this post will describe each of these steps in more detail, with pictures!

Coherent Stacking

Each trace that is recorded to disk corresponds to the data from 8 pulses, summed in hardware. Flying at 100m/s, this still corresponds to data every 12.5cm along the flight path. This is excessive if our goal is to create an image for human interpretation. Additional stacking boosts the signal to noise ratio, decreases data storage requirements, decreases processing time, and improves horizontal resolution.

Given that the antennas' along-track beam width is \(\sim150^\circ\) and our airplane is hundreds of meters to several kilometers above the surface of interest, we don't expect any significant change in the recorded signal between adjacent traces. Therefore, simply adding \(n\) traces will in theory boost your SNR by \(\sqrt{n}\).4 For our application, this breaks down if the range to the surface changes enough to cause signals to destructively interfere. Thus, the ideal number of traces to combine depends on the radar's wavelength and how quickly the range to the surface changes along-track. In the images above, the left has no stacking, the middle has 10 traces stacked, and the right has 100 traces stacked.

In practice, we have found 10 to work well at this stage. If we were only worried about the pulse-limited footprint, we could in theory stack for \(\sim\)40m along-track (above, left). However, surface slopes provide a stronger bound (above, right).

In addition to increasing the SNR along a trace, stacking improves the along-track resolution. This technique is also referred to as "unfocused Synthetic Aperture Radar"5 or "coherent integration."6

Side Note: Coherence

In the context of radar, coherence refers to the ability to recover phase information about the signal. This is important for dechirping and focusing. For a long time, this terminology confused me because I hadn't realized that "coherent" can be used to mean slightly different things when describing the instrument, the environment, and the processing.

At the instrument level, coherence requires sending out pulses of energy where the phase is always consistent with respect to the start of the pulse. If you generated the output signal using an unsychronized oscillator and a blanking signal, you'd have an incoherent radar.7 Coherence also requires sampling the returned signal at a high enough frequency to recover the phase information.

For the environment, a surface can either reflect energy with the same phase as it was incident, or can randomize the phases. A uniform smooth flat surface will be coherent, whereas one that's rough may be incoherent.

Finally, some steps in our processing pipeline retain phase information, and later ones operate only on amplitudes. Reducing different types of noise require coherent or incoherent techniques. The ordering is important since once you've discarded phase information you can't get it back.

Dechirping

Dechirping is a simple concept- just convolve the reference chirp along each trace. This means that a single peak in the returned data (corresponding to a change in dielectric properties in the ice, or an air/ice/bed interface) will be magnified by xxx dB. If an interface is strong enough, you'll also see the sidelobes in the convolution, as shown below.

Since convolution is distributive over addition, results don't depend on the ordering of the coherent stacking and the dechirping. Stacking first requires fewer computations, so we do that.

In practice, this convolution is performed using a FFT and iFFT, since \(F*H = iFFT[FFT(F) FFT(H)]\), and a FFT is \(O(nlogn)\), while convolution is \(O(n^2)\). However, there are a few additional subtleties to the convolution in practice:

Give a pointer to http://jackschaedler.github.io/circles-sines-signals/sound.html for more details about basic signal processing.

Side Note: Why Chirp?

Why do we transmit a chirped signal?

We use a chirped pulse because it allows us to greatly improve effective vertical resolution over a constant-frequency pulse. The diagram below shows an idealized example of trying to determine the range to a surface, based on the reflected signal. For a constant frequency pulse, the best you can do is ????.

For a chirp, effective vertical resolution is 1/bandwidth. For us, this translates to ??m in air, or ??m in ice.

reference chirp

We don't actually use the idealized reference chirp from the signal generator; both the amplifier and the antennas distort the signal. (As does interaction with the air, and ice.) Instead, we use an empiricaly-derived reference chirp [I think this is pretty much just based on "what looks good". At one point, we tried to derive this from the reflection on open water, but that wound up just being a really good water detector.

Denoising

However, we can do better than simple deconvolution with

hamming filter

In the field, we'll use a hamming filter to make the resulting image clearer. A hamming filter lowers the power of the sidelobes involved in dechirping.

Local Oscillator Leakage

For a number of years, our receiver design involved amplification, frequency mixing with a 70MHz local oscillator (to downconvert the 60MHz center frequency to 10MHz), low pass filtering, and finally, sampling at 50MHz. 8 A very small amount of energy from this local oscillator made it through the system even when there was no signal from the antennas. This results in the horizontal stripes seen in the images above. 9

This doesn't even show up in the FFT of the full image, but if we look at the spectrum of noise below the bed reflection we'll see them show up!

TODO: Try plotting the FFT on a log plot?

The hamming filter removes the highest-gain components, but we still have the harmonics that show up right in the middle of the chirp. These don't show up as stripes in the final data products, but instead raise the level of background noise, which directly impacts how weak of a signal we can detect.

This correction is very cheap - we've already taken the FFT in order to efficiently dechirp the data, so we just use the FFT of the noise (computed once per transect) to determine how much to subtract from the corresponding frequency bin of the full trace's FFT.

Older Data

This FFT-based noise rejection is a recent change in the processing pipeline. If you look at some of our older published radargrams, you'll see vertical streaks that are an artifact of the prior approach. In that version, rather than subtracting off a calculated amount from the appropriate bins, we simply replaced those values with an interpolation between neighboring bins.

Incoherent Stacking:

Incoherent stacking is used to reduce data size (we generate products that are consistent with data from decades ago) and to reduce speckle. No amount of coherent addition will remove speckle - it just changes where the nulls are. However, as soon as you sum magnitudes the problem of phase interference causing nulls or peaks goes away.

Side Note: Speckle

TODO: I talked w/ Scott and Greg, and it's apparently a common phenomenon that happens whenever you have coherent signals adding - random scattering will cause interference, and you'll get zeros where they don't belong. You can see this if you look closely at a laser pointer's dot.

Overall Complexity:

Check these with a line profiler:

  • coherent Stacking requires one addition per sample per trace, so it's \(O(xy)\)
  • dechirping requires \(O(\frac{x}{y} y log_{10} y)\) operations for the FFT where n is the stacking depth
  • incoherent stacking requires \(O(y\frac{x}{n})\) additions.

  • RTQC - We are able to monitor the instruments while flying. This includes looking at a subsampled version of the de-chirped radargram discussed a few paragraphs down.
  • Hard drives - we record simultaneously to the hard drive on the RTQC computer and to external SSD drives. Ideally, we just carry the SSD drive back to the tent or office where we're doing data processing. Having to download 100GB of data from the computer onto a drive is an annoying delay.

entry.title: Pelican Basics
entry.summary:
I'd put off switching to Pelican and learning about CSS&HTML for ages because it seemed like I needed to know so.much.stuff. and didn't know how it all fit together. Once I sat down and just did it, it took less than a day, including the time required to recreate my favorite theme from elsewhere.

I'm now a big fan of Pelican - I'm finding it easy to set up, and easy to modify. I just switched from octopress b/c I prefer python to ruby, and pelican seems way more logically structured and easy to modify.

Eventually, my distaste for web programming was overpowered by my distaste for using an easy-to-break tool and not knowing enough to fix it. One of the reasons I was avoiding this was because I didn't know where to start, and it seemed like there was so much stuff to learn, and I didn't know how it all fit together. It turned out to not be nearly as annoying as I'd expected.

Setup

This bit was really well documented elsewhere, and a ridiculously smooth experience. Set up the blog locally. Push to github pages. Done.

Themes

Pelican has a bunch of themes available. Just clone this repository, and change the THEME variable in pelicanconf.py.

However, I'm picky. I'd discovered the leanpress theme for Octopress, but couldn't find a version for Pelican, and couldn't find an existing one I liked as much.

So, time to learn about CSS & HTML. It turns out that the basics are really, really basic:

  • HTML is used to describe the content of the pages, and the links between them. The raw template files made sense without any additional knowledge.
  • CSS is used to describe how to format the content from the HTML. Reading the first few pages of the Mozilla tutorial gave me enough to go on with. I'm still in need of a more condensed reference.
  • ??? - provides additional markup tags for the HTML templates that specify how the content from the blog posts gets inserted.

That's it. All I needed to know to customize a theme.

I started with a pelican theme with similar logical structure (cleanelican, itself a port of the cleanpress octopress theme), and copied over the css details from the octopress theme that I liked. This was tedious, but easy enough. I'm sure it could be prettier, but it works and I'm moving on.

Plugins

OK, now I have a pretty blog. But what if I want the ability to display \(\LaTeX\) or easier-to-insert footnotes?

Clone the pelican-plugins repo, then edit pelicanconf.py to set the PLUGIN_PATHS variable to wherever you put it, and PLUGINS to be a list of which ones you want enabled.

These operate on the ???html/markup??? to do stuff like better picture formatting or footnotes. The best bit is that they're written in python, so when it doesn't do what I expected or two of 'em clash, it's really easy to just open up the source code and see what's going on.

entry.title: A Brief Introduction to Ice-Penetrating Radar
entry.summary:
I've been working with ice-penetrating radar data for years, and I still think it's so flipping cool that we can see through kilometers of ice using radar. This is possible because ice is mostly transparent to electromagnetic energy at radar frequencies. We see reflections at the air/ice interface, within the ice where its properties change, and at the ice/rock (or ice/water) interface.

Over the last few decades1, my group has collected airborne ice-penetrating data all over Antarctica:

In order to collect this data, we mount antennas and recording equipment on a modified DC3. These are unpressurized WWII-era airplanes that have been updated with new engines. The left image below shows JKB taking off from the Casey skiway; the right image shows one of my colleagues monitoring the instruments during a flight. As the plane flies, the radar transmits 6250 pulses every second. After each pulse, it listens for reflected energy; this returned signal is what you're looking at in the radargram.2

I spend a lot of time studying radar profiles like the one below. The x-axis is distance along the flight line, and the y-axis is height.3 In effect, we're looking at a slice of the ice sheet. White corresponds to a strong reflection, and we can clearly see the surface and bed all along the transect. This particular profile is running along the Totten Ice Shelf; it is highlighted in red on the right (zoomed-in) image below. The star indicates the start of the profile. Note how the bed signal gets weaker as we cross the grounding zone - radar energy reflects more strongly from water than from rock.

Totten Glacier is interesting because it is losing mass relatively quickly, as determined by satellite gravity4 and altimetry.5 Among other things, radar data is used in areas like this to better determine the location of the grounding line and to calculate the volume of ice in the drainage feeding an outlet glacier.6

Multiple Reflections

When looking at radargrams, another thing to watch out for are multiple reflections, which can be confused for the bed or a layer. These most commonly occur when the radar energy bounces back off the plane, to the surface, and back to the plane. It is possible to distinguish such a multiple from a true layer because it is always the same distance below the surface as the plane is above the surface, which means that the multiple's apparent slope is twice that of the surface's. An example of this type of multiple can be found in the Totten transect above. Below, we have data from over the Ross Ice Shelf. The ice shelf is thin enough, and the bottom echo strong enough, that we see multiples due to the radar energy bouncing between the ice's interfaces, as well as back off the plane.

Beam Pattern

Radar data can be more difficult to interpret than laser data because the beam pattern is not anywhere near as focused. This means that the energy received at a given point in space is not necessarily a reflection from directly below the airplane, as would be most convenient/intuitive to assume. On our airplane, the along-track pattern is a single lobe with half power at 152-degrees (below, left). Cross-track, the first lobe is at 22-degrees, and is only 2.4dB weaker than the main lobe directly below the airplane (below, right).

(Figures from7, showing the antenna's gain in dB as a function of angle.)

Reflections from the side

The previous radargram has an undulating surface that could be confused for the bottom of an ice shelf. However, looking at a map, we can see that this region is either open water or sea ice. The location of the ice shelf's edge roughly matches the reflector's geometry, so this is actually the side of the ice shelf reflecting energy from one of the sidelobes! Echoes off to the side aren't always so easy to interpret. Here's a more confusing transect flying along a valley:

A number of research groups are actively working on how to determine whether a signal is a side echo or originates from directly below the aircraft, but it's not yet a solved problem. Techniques that have been tried include recording from multiple antennas at the same time and comparing the phase difference,8 or comparing the radar data to a known elevation map of the surface.9

Reflections from ahead/behind

The wide beam pattern along-track also means that a strong reflector will be seen long before/after we actually fly over it. These show up as hyperbolas in the radargram, as illustrated in the cartoon below:

Crevasses are very good reflectors since a corner will reflect energy along the same path that it came in on. They show up well in some regions of the Totten Ice Shelf transect above. Man-made structures also show up as strong reflectors. In the radargram below, we see South Pole Station as a set of hyperbolas. Their peaks appear below the surface reflection because this transect didn't directly cross the station - it was about a kilometer to the side.

There are existing processing techniques for dealing with a wide along-track beam angle that reduce the appearance of hyperbolas. The basic idea is that you've observed the same location from a number of different positions as you're flying over it, and can use that redundancy to figure out where the "real" reflector is,10 but the details are a topic for another post.

The radargram above has striking layers which are also wonderfully useful for modelling the ice sheet. A lot of work is done to correlate layers observed in radargrams to ice properties directly measured from a drilled core. This is analogous to studying tree rings, but over a much longer time frame. There are ice cores from East Antarctica that provide a climate record for the last 800,000 years.11 Once you have this correlation, and if you can trace a continuous layer across a region, you then know the age-depth relationship for the ice sheet. The deformation of layers also contains information about how the ice has been moving.

A colleague claims that no presentation about Antarctica is complete without a penguin. They're far too small to show up in radar data, but here's a picture of a pair from Shirley Island, near Casey Station:
